;东南亚国家正在制定人工智能 (AI) 的治理和道德准则，五名直接了解此事的官员表示，将对蓬勃发展的技术设置“护栏”。

;

;世界各地的监管机构都在加紧起草法规，以管理生成式 AI 的使用，生成式 AI 可以创建文本和图像东南亚国家联盟（东盟）10 个成员国的部长们在 2 月份同意有必要发展一个东盟针对该地区 6.68 亿人口的“人工智能指南”，但此前并未报道区域政策制定者讨论的细节。

;

;东南亚高级官员表示，所谓的东盟人工智能治理和道德指南是正在成形，并将尝试在该技术的经济利益与其诸多风险之间取得平衡。

;

;“起草工作正在进行中，可能会在今年年底完成，然后才会得到东盟成员国的认可，”一位官员说。

;

;欧盟立法者批准了关于集团未来 AI 规则的计划

;

;另一位官员表示，该计划可能会在明年初的东盟数字部长会议上宣布。

;< p>; 新加坡通信和信息部发言人表示，作为 2024 年会议的主席，该国将与其他东盟国家合作“制定一份‘东盟人工智能治理和道德指南’，作为一个实用且可实施的指南”支持在东盟可靠地部署负责任和创新的 AI 技术。”

;

;其他东盟国家包括文莱、柬埔寨、印度尼西亚、老挝、马来西亚、缅甸、菲律宾、新加坡、泰国和越南。无法立即联系到这些政府发表评论。

;

;考虑到讨论的早期阶段和东盟进程的机密性，消息人士拒绝进一步评论 AI 指南的样子。

; p>;消息来源包括三个东南亚国家的官员，他们拒绝透露姓名，因为他们无权向媒体发表讲话。

;

;随着欧盟和预计美国将在数周内发布一份自愿性 AI 行为准则草案。该准则将在欧盟开创性的 AI 法案之前生效，该法案仍在讨论中。

;

;与欧洲和美国的同行一样，区域决策者对 AI 可能将错误信息工业化表示特别担忧。< /p>;

;新加坡信息通信媒体发展局在 6 月份的一份研究论文中警告说，当生成式人工智能以令人信服的确定性产生似是而非的内容时，存在“幻觉”的风险。

;

;这个岛国一直处于据三位消息人士透露，该地区人工智能战略的前沿，并正在牵头起草人工智能指南。

;美国敦促对被骗进入欺诈交易的人采取更人道的态度他们也是人口贩运的受害者，因为大规模的网络欺诈流行病继续席卷亚洲。

;

;美国国务院周四发布的年度人口贩运报告 (TIP) 敦促各国政府提供幸存者人口贩运保护免受“不当惩罚和进一步受害”。

;

;报告发布之际，专家表示，数以万计的年轻男女仍然是诈骗团伙的俘虏，这些团伙利用他们在亚洲及其他地区的网络上以弱势群体为目标庞氏骗局、虚假的加密货币投资以及虚构的浪漫承诺。

;

;亚洲的诈骗危机：假身份证、银行信函、“大红旗”中的悲催故事

;

;这些庞大的诈骗活动，通常由华人主导的犯罪集团经营，用虚假工作机会欺骗精通技术的年轻工人，引诱他们到缅甸、柬埔寨、老挝、菲律宾的“诈骗工厂”从事高薪工作，结果证明是骗局。

;

;一些成功逃脱的人——通常是通过支付数千美元的释放费——讲述了他们因非法越境而被长期拘留，然后因参与诈骗交易而被起诉的故事。

;

;报告称：“这些人经常被追究责任并面临各种形式的惩罚，包括罚款、拘留、起诉、定罪和驱逐出境。”

;

;但惩罚这些受害者的后果会破坏更大范围的反贩运努力报告补充说，由于害怕受到惩罚，受害者不愿寻求保护和帮助。

;

;这个问题变得复杂，因为亚洲当局正在与一场从受害者身上席卷数亿美元的祸害作斗争。

;

;老挝和泰国的几名诈骗代理人此前告诉《亚洲周刊》，他们在前往诈骗中心时就知道自己会遇到什么。但专家表示，恐怕还有数以万计的其他人被欺骗和贩运成为骗子。

;

;TIP 报告有一个四级系统，该系统基于政府为达到美国消除标准而做出的努力该国的《贩运受害者保护法》(TVPA) 中规定的人口贩运。

;

;新加坡和菲律宾排名最高，为第 1 级，而包括中国、柬埔寨和阿富汗在内的国家/地区位于第 3 级，最低评级表明没有在打击人口贩运方面做出重大努力。

;

;今年的报告中有 106 个二级管辖区，包括孟加拉国、日本、印度尼西亚和印度。

;

;马来西亚移动从去年的 Tier 3 上升到 Tier 2 观察名单，这意味着虽然它没有达到 TVPA 的最低标准，但它在过去一年中做出了重大努力来遵守这些标准。

;

;报告指出，马来西亚在过去的一年里，通过发起更多的贩运调查、起诉和定罪更多的贩运者以及迫害同谋官员，取得了重大成就。

;

;但是，在起诉该国棕榈油行业和手套制造业的劳务贩运者方面还需要做更多的工作

;

;说英语的菲律宾人被骗到中国骗局：告密者

;

;报告还说，必须加大对涉及共谋官员和强迫劳动犯罪的贩卖案件的起诉力度，

;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯 (Antony Blinken) 在报告发布的讲话中强调了政府、非政府组织、民间社会和私营行业（包括科技行业）之间合作的重要性, 以打击性和劳工贩运。

;

;“美国致力于打击人口贩运，因为它代表了对人权和自由的攻击。<​​/p>;

;“它侵犯了普遍权利每个人都有自主权。今天，全世界有超过 2700 万人被剥夺了这一权利，”他说。

;上海证券交易所已批准先正达集团 650 亿元人民币（91 亿美元）的首次公开募股首次公开募股 (IPO)，这可能是今年在中国商业中心举行的全球最大的股票发售。

;

;先正达在上海证券交易所网站上发布的一份声明中获得了批准。根据先正达的招股说明书草案，该公司计划出售至多 27.8 亿元人民币的 A 股，以为其研发提供资金，升级其农业平台，支持全球收购并偿还长期债务。

;

;在 3 月份上海证券交易所在预定会议前夕突然取消其 IPO 审查的戏剧性障碍之后，绿灯对先正达来说是一个巧妙的转变。这家总部位于瑞士的公司自 2017 年以来由国有企业中国化工集团公司（中国化工）持有其 99.1% 的股份，上个月正式撤回其科创板 IPO 计划，转而在上海主板上市。

;

;先正达的 IPO根据彭博社的数据，由中国国际金融公司 (CICC)、中银国际和中信证券承销的该药物将超过美国消费者健康公司 Kenvue 上月 ​​43.7 亿美元的发行。这也将成为继中国农业银行 2010 年 100 亿美元上市后中国第二大IPO。

;

;今年，中国公司在上海、深圳和北京交易所通过首次公开募股共筹资 298 亿美元，彭博数据显示，香港和纽约分别超过 21 亿美元和 61 亿美元。

;

;此次发售预计将在未来几个月向散户投资者开放，将测试中国 82 - 万亿元股市，在经济增长乏力的情况下，市场情绪仍然不稳定。根据彭博社的数据，中国的沪深 300 指数今年上涨了 2.4%，在亚洲 87 个股指中排名第 36 位。

;

;先正达不会立即获得离岸北向交易的资格投资者通过沪港通，但必须等待上海证券交易所的审查和批准，全球资金才能通过香港账户涉足其股票。

;

;不过，先正达的重磅报价仍然炙手可热继中国大陆 IPO 改革之后，以基于需求的市场定价取代了之前 23 倍市盈率的价格上限。

;

;为什么习近平的万亿宝贝超越了亚洲的增长市场

;

;先正达在2017年被中国化工以430亿美元收购，成为中国企业最大的海外收购案。收购后，农化集团不断扩大业务范围，收购了以色列农作物保护公司阿达玛的股份，并合并了中国化工和中化集团的农业部门。

;

;巴塞尔农化集团一季度利润该公司的招股说明书显示，由于支付更高的利率，该公司比去年下降了 18%，而收入增长了 11%。

; Fri, 16 Jun 2023 17:20:02 +0800 China’s top naval scientist proposes a Star Wars-style ‘supership’ to convert nuclear energy to kinetic force weaponshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3224315/chinas-top-naval-scientist-proposes-star-wars-style-supership-convert-nuclear-energy-kinetic-force?utm_source=rss_feed

;中国最先进海军技术发展的关键人物马伟明少将, 透露了一艘未来派军舰的概念蓝图，他说这艘军舰不同于世界上任何一艘船。

;

;“它将彻底颠覆已经存在一百多年的海军舰队作战编队”，他在 6 月 13 日发表在《中国电工技术学报》期刊上的一篇同行评议论文中说。

;

;目前，世界各地的海军作战平台、航空母舰群因多样性而变得更加复杂他们必须执行的任务。这使他们更难有效地协调他们的行动。这些船只的建造和运营成本也很高。

;

;马云和他的同事在论文中描述了一种新的海军作战系统时说，中国所谓的超级舰船几乎可以完成整个航母舰队的工作将电磁武器和强大的核动力电力系统结合在一起。

;

;根据马的论文中计算机生成的照片，这艘军舰载有大量飞机，但与传统航母不同。

;

;虽然许多航空母舰都是核动力的，但它们的电气系统通常设计用于为船舶的推进系统和其他基本系统提供动力。它们的主要作用是为海军行动提供空中支援，而不是直接参与战斗。

;

;这艘超级战舰配备了新型电磁武器，例如轨道炮、线圈炮、火箭发射器、激光武器和高-

;

;该论文称，该船的先进技术“巧妙而有效地将来自船舶电源的能量转化为为高能武器提供动力所需的电磁能”。

;

;这可以使单艘军舰具备准确防御空袭、进行反潜战、拦截导弹以及对海陆目标进行精确打击的能力。

;

;“因此，单艘多用途船可以执行常规舰队的传统任务，”马说。

;

;目前，核能不能用作常规战争中的武器。

;

;欧盟将中国公司从因军用物资流向俄罗斯而被列入制裁名单中剔除

;

;马的团队表示，这艘超级飞船的综合核动力电磁系统可以将核能转化为可用的动能或电力，以驱动高能武器系统。

;

;该报称，例如，船上的电磁轨道炮射程很远，可以用高达七倍音速的制导弹药击中临近空间的目标。

;

;研究人员表示，电磁发射的导弹可以像自动步枪一样自动重新装弹，发射速度和数量远高于对手。

;

;并且电磁线圈枪可以发射不同类型的导弹水下武器，显着增强船舶的水下攻击和防御能力。

;

;激光武器利用光速传输能量，可实现极其精确的瞄准。另一方面，高能微波武器的杀伤范围广，可以同时对付多个目标。

;

;得益于近乎取之不竭的核能供应和先进的电力管理系统，超级飞船也将该论文称，配备强大的雷达和其他耗电传感器，可以比以往任何时候都更远地探测敌人。

;

;马云的团队没有估计何时建造超级飞船，但它表示中国已准备好将科幻小说中的想法带入现实世界。

;

;在论文中，海军研究人员列出了中国最近取得的突破，这些突破将为该舰的建造铺平道路。其中一些是首次解密。

;

;例如，据称，中国海军已经开发并实施了一种用于各种类型作战平台（包括车辆、船舶和潜艇）的武器有效载荷的电磁发射系统。

;

;“目前，中国已经解决了包括车载、舰载和水下系统在内的各类作战平台武器载荷电磁发射系统的所有关键技术，”他说。论文。

;

;电发射导弹系统是一种利用电磁能发射导弹的系统。

;

;电发射导弹系统的一个主要优点是它允许快速和反复发射导弹。传统的导弹发射系统通常需要大量时间来装弹和准备发射，而电动发射导弹系统可以自动装弹，从而可以快速、持续地发射导弹。

;

;如果传统的当航空母舰舰队接近超级舰队并意图发动协同攻击时，超级舰队可以使用其电导弹发射系统向航母舰队发射一连串导弹。

;

;电导弹发射系统将使航母舰队难以规避或防御来袭导弹。

;

;电导弹发射系统相对于传统导弹发射系统的优势类似于自动步枪优于单发步枪，可以更快速、更有效地打击目标，这可能决定海战的胜负。

;

;中国是迄今为止唯一进行过射击试验的国家海上的大型轨道炮。马军说，中国海军工程大学最近在小型电磁炮研制方面取得了多项重大突破。

;

;这些进展包括使发射装置和电源更轻，集成电磁炮武器系统并采用弹丸匹配和电磁旋升技术提高射击精度。

;

;世界上当前枪支的射程和动能记录，”马说。

;

;典型的 9 毫米手枪子弹的枪口能量约为 500 焦耳。这意味着中国研制的电磁炮的杀伤力至少是一般9毫米手枪的100倍左右。

;

;中国目前还在研发电磁线圈发射技术，可以发射高达1000米的炮弹根据该论文，每秒米（3,280 英尺），或音速的三倍多。

;

;美国海军的“闪电航母概念”为中国军队提供了经验教训

;

;线圈炮使用一系列电磁线圈来加速弹丸，而轨道炮使用平行轨道来产生推动弹丸的磁场。这种设计上的差异使得线圈炮更易于建造和维护。

;

;马说，近年来中国海军电磁发射技术的应用是经过二十多年努力和与对手激烈竞争的结果

;

;“自 1980 年代以来，美国……一直是该领域的领导者，”他说。但是从世纪之交开始，中国科学家比他们的竞争对手得到了政府更多的持续支持。

;

;例如，CG(X) 项目是美国海军的一个项目，旨在开发一种新型的导弹巡洋舰，本来应该配备先进的武器系统，包括电磁发射系统。

;

;该计划于 2010 年被取消，原因是“技术要求太高，成本太高”，Ma

;

;美国海军的轨道炮计划是另一个开发用于未来战争的大功率轨道炮的项目。但该计划面临供电和散热等技术挑战，近年来规模缩减。

;

;美国在发展电磁发射系统方面面临一些挑战，不得不缩减规模或由于技术挑战和预算限制而取消一些项目。

;

;这减缓了美国在这一领域的进展，并使中国有机会在开发更先进和有效的电磁发射系统的竞赛中获得优势.

;

;例如，中国海军研制的脉冲储能模块，可以储存数百千焦的能量，并可以模块化积木的方式组合，实现数百兆焦的总储能，

;

;这是电磁发射用大容量脉冲储能系统发展的重大突破，其性能是美国海军使用的同类系统的数倍。

;

;马说，中国还开发了一种用于电磁发射系统的高抗过载能力的 GNC（制导、导航和控制）模块。

;

;该模块旨在提供精确的制导和控制发射过程中的弹丸，即使在弹丸承受高达重力 35,000 倍的极端力的高过载情况下也是如此。

;

;导轨炮弹丸可以主动将自身转向预定目标，补偿风、重力或目标移动等因素。

;

;这提高了准确击中目标的机会，尤其是在远距离时。

;

;香港当局查获了价值 2200 万港元（280 万美元）的违禁品ranging from dried shark fins to live star tortoises in a month-long crackdown against the smuggling of endangered wildlife.

;

;Assistant Superintendent Cheung Ka-chung of customs' air cargo group on Friday said authorities cracked 24 smuggling cases involving endangered species at various control points, including the airport, in the May operation that also led to the arrests of 14 people.

;

;In one of the cases, customs officers seized more than five tonnes of dried shark fins from suspected endangered species with an estimated value of HK$21 million, he said.

;

;Cheung added that the fins were found stashed in two shipping containers delivered to the city from Macau on May 4.

;

;Officers also seized four protected star tortoises in a parcel airmailed into the city from Malaysia on May 25. The live animals were estimated to be worth HK$36,000.

;

;2 Hong Kong men arrested for allegedly smuggling endangered species products

;

;Other suspected endangered species seized in the operation included ginseng, dried seahorses and orchids.

;

;According to the Customs and Excise Department, the operation was jointly mounted with officers from the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department in response to a rising trend in the smuggling of endangered species.

;

;Figures show customs cracked 175 smuggling cases involving endangered species in the first five months of the year, accounting for 60 per cent of the 291 cases logged in the whole of 2022.

;

;Cheung said the number of cases dropped from 659 in 2019 to an average annual figure of some 300 in the past three years because of a dramatic decrease in air, sea and land travel during the Covid-19 pandemic.

;

;He said authorities noticed a rising trend of smuggling of endangered species this year following the resumption of normal travel amid eased Covid curbs.

;

;Cheung warned the public not to bring endangered species products into or out of the city without a valid licence. He added that frontline officers would continue to remain vigilant at control points and enhance intelligence collection to combat such activities.

;

;Hong Kong customs arrests 5 men, seizes HK$200 million worth of contraband

;

;In Hong Kong, importing or exporting endangered species without a permit carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in jail and a HK$10 million fine.

;

;According to customs, smuggling is a serious offence and those found importing and exporting unmanifested cargo face a maximum penalty of seven years behind bars and a HK$2 million fine.

; Fri, 16 Jun 2023 14:50:01 +0800 How much prison time could Donald Trump face?https://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3224301/how-much-prison-time-could-donald-trump-face?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.16 14:26;
;;

;The FBI investigators who searched Harold Martin's Maryland property in the fall of 2016 found classified documents – including material at the top secret level – strewn about his home, car and storage shed.

;

;Unlike former president Donald Trump, the former National Security Agency contractor didn't contest the allegations, ultimately pleading guilty in 2019 and admitting his actions were “wrong, illegal and highly questionable”.

;

;But his expressions of contrition and guilty plea to a single count of wilful retention of national defence information didn't spare him the harsh punishment of nine years in prison.

;

;The resolution of that case looms as an ominous guidepost for the legal jeopardy Trump could face as he confronts 37 felony counts – 31 under the same century-old Espionage Act statute used to prosecute Martin and other defendants alleged to have illegally retained classified documents.

;

;Even many like Martin who have pleaded guilty and accepted responsibility have nonetheless been socked with years-long prison sentences.

;

;“When they decide to pursue a wilful mishandling case, it's to send a message: that we take these cases very seriously,” said Michael Zweiback, a defence lawyer and former Justice Department prosecutor. “They almost always are seeking jail time.”

;

;Trump's arraignment took 45 minutes, but path to trial may take a couple years

;

;How much prison time the former president could face in the event of a conviction is impossible to say, with such a decision ultimately up to the trial judge – in this case, a Trump appointee who has already demonstrated a willingness to rule in his favour.

;

;It's also hard to know the extent to which other factors – including the logistical and political complications of jailing a former president – might play a role.

;

;The Espionage Act offence is punishable by up to 10 years in prison, though it's rare for first-time federal offenders to get close to the maximum.

;

;But beyond the retention, prosecutors have also identified multiple aggravating factors in Trump's alleged conduct, accusing him of seeking to enlist others – including a lawyer and aides – to hide the records from investigators and showing off some to visitors.

;

;Some of the other counts in the indictment, including conspiracy to obstruct justice, call for up to 20 years in prison.

;

;Justice Department prosecutors in recent years have used the Espionage Act provision against a variety of defendants, including a West Virginia woman who retained an NSA document related to a foreign government's military and political issues.

;

;Elizabeth Jo Shirley pleaded guilty in 2020 to a wilful retention count and was sentenced to eight years in prison.

;

;This month, a retired US Air Force intelligence officer named Robert Birchum was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to keeping classified files at his home, his overseas officer's quarters and a storage pod in his driveway.

;

;Many defendants have pleaded guilty, rather than face trial, though not all have gone to prison.

;

;Trump – who also faces charges related to hush-money payments in New York state court – has shown no signs that he could be headed toward a plea deal, vigorously insisting he is innocent and personally attacking Justice Department special counsel Jack Smith hours after appearing in Miami federal court Tuesday.

;

;Despite the details in the indictment, Trump does have some avenues to try to contest the charges.

;

;For one thing, he's drawn Judge Aileen Cannon, who sided with Trump last year in the former president's bid to appoint a special master to conduct an independent review of the seized classified documents.

;

;Citing the “stigma” she said was associated with an FBI search of Trump's home, she said a “future indictment” based on items that should've been returned to Trump “would result in reputational harm of a decidedly different order of magnitude”.

;

;A three-judge panel of the US Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit unanimously overturned her ruling, which was widely criticised by legal experts as extraordinary and unusually broad.

;

;Over the next several months, Cannon will make decisions that will shape the trial, including how quickly it will happen and whether any evidence will be kept out.

;

;Prosecutors also face the challenge in Florida – where Republicans have made steady inroads in recent years – of a jury pool likely to be more favourable to Trump than if the case were tried in overwhelmingly Democratic Washington DC.

;

;Trump declares 'food for everyone', leaves restaurant without paying

;

;Still, “I think that it might very well be that Jack Smith welcomes a Florida jury because if there is a conviction, it will be much harder to say, 'Well, that jury was somehow anti-Trump,'” said Stephen Saltzburg, a George Washington University law school professor and former Justice Department official.

;

;Experts anticipate Trump's lawyers to echo the former president's public remarks in trying to get the case dismissed by arguing he was entitled to have the documents and is the victim of prosecutorial overreach.

;

;Trump could also try to block prosecutors from being able to use key evidence, such as notes from his lawyer detailing conversations with the former president.

;

;If the case gets to trial, experts say Trump's lawyers may attempt what's called “jury nullification” or try to convince jurors that he should be acquitted even if they believe Trump broke the law because the violation wasn't serious enough to warrant charges and he is being singled out.

;

;“The theme of the defence can be riddled with suggestions of unfairness and selective prosecution – basically trying to convince a jury that even if the former president did what the government says he did, none of this should have ever ended up in a criminal prosecution,” said Robert Mintz, a defence lawyers and former Justice Department prosecutor.

;

;Robert Kelner, a Washington criminal defence lawyer, said while an outright acquittal seems unlikely given the volume of evidence, a pathway for a mistrial exists if Trump lawyers can persuade even one juror to acquit on grounds that the president enjoyed the absolute authority to declassify information.

;

;That authority ended the moment Trump left the presidency, but even so, “some jurors will likely find it hard to rationalise convicting him for something that he previously had the absolute authority (to do) simply because he didn't file the right forms and do it at the right time,” Kelner said.

;

;In the end, facing a mountain of evidence and the prospect of years in prison, Trump's best hope may be a tactic he often pursues: delay, delay, delay, said Cheryl Bader, a former federal prosecutor and head of Fordham University Law School's Criminal Defence Clinic.

;

;“His best defence may be to try to ride out the election cycle, be elected as president and therefore be in charge of the Justice Department before the case goes to trial,” she said.

;Japan's age of consent was raised from 13, among the world's lowest, to 16 years old on Friday as lawmakers passed key reforms to sex crime legislation.

;

;A new bill, which also clarifies rape prosecution requirements and criminalises voyeurism, cleared parliament's upper house in a unanimous vote.

;

;The age of consent – below which sexual activity is considered statutory rape – is 16 in Britain, 15 in France, and 14 in Germany and China.

;

;Japan's had been unchanged since 1907, with children aged 13 and above deemed capable of consent.

;

;In practice, across many parts of the country, regional ordinances banning “lewd” acts with minors are sometimes seen as effectively raising the age of consent to 18.

;

;Johnny Kitagawa sex abuse claims prompt questions over Japan media's complicity

;

;Under the new law, teen couples no more than five years apart in age will be exempt from prosecution if both partners are over 13.

;

;Japan last revised its criminal code on sexual offences in 2017, for the first time in more than a century, but campaigners said the reforms were insufficient.

;

;And in 2019, a string of acquittals in rape cases triggered nationwide rallies.

;

;Under the previous law, prosecutors had to prove victims were incapacitated due to violence and intimidation.

;

;Critics argued that requirement effectively blamed victims for not resisting enough.

;

;The bill that passed on Friday contains a list of examples under which rape prosecutions can be made.

;

;These include victims being under the influence of alcohol or drugs, being frightened, and perpetrators taking advantage of social status.

;

;A justice ministry official said earlier this year that the clarifications were not “meant to make it easier or harder” to secure rape convictions, but “will hopefully make court verdicts more consistent”.

;

;The bill also contains a new “visitation request offence”, according to the justice ministry.

;

;It means that people who use intimidation, seduction or money to coerce children under 16 to meet for sexual purposes will face a prison sentence of up to a year or a fine of 500,000 yen (US$3,500).

;Taiwanese investment in Singapore has surged over the past two years as the city state has become a refuge for money to hedge against the risk of a military conflict with mainland China, according to official data and analysts.

;

;In 2020, just S$3.69 billion (US$2.8 billion) in Taiwanese money reached Singapore's enterprises, funds and other assets after only S$1.48 billion made it in 2019.

;

;But direct investment flows from Taiwan to Singapore reached S$7.21 billion (US$5.4 billion) in 2021 and S$6.1 billion last year, according to Singapore's Department of Statistics.

;

;“In Taiwan, what they have on their minds is a lot of uncertainty, given the tense relations with China,” said Kent Chong, managing director at professional services firm PwC Legal in Taipei, who manages clients looking to take money off the island.

;

;“There is anxiety on the part of their funds.”

;

;Taiwanese investment funds, companies and wealthy individuals favour Singapore over other countries because they believe it is politically “neutral” with options for residency, if needed, Chong added.

;

;The turn toward Singapore may have started because of strict coronavirus controls that “undermined business activities” in mainland China, said Wang Wei-chieh, a Taiwan-based foreign affairs analyst and inbound foreign service master's student at Georgetown University.

;

;'A permanent home': why a wave of wealthy Chinese is moving to Singapore

;

;Taiwanese businesspeople have, Wang added, traditionally favoured investing in mainland China.

;

;Since the 1980s, Taiwanese investors have regarded mainland China as a place to manufacture goods for the Chinese market or for re-export to other countries.

;

;But lockdowns flared up in early 2020 and again last year, hobbling factories and slowing shipments of goods through ports.

;

;“Also, the rising geopolitical tensions between the US and China and across the [Taiwan Strait] could play a role behind these investors' calculations,” Wang said.

;

;Beijing sees self-ruled Taiwan as a breakaway territory that must be reunified, by force if necessary. Cross-strait tensions have risen in recent years and peaked in August, when former US House speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taiwan. This prompted massive military drills by mainland China in the waters near the self-ruled island and trade sanctions on Taiwan exports.

;

;Many foreign business operators in Taiwan have their own contingency plans in place in case of any potential conflict with mainland China, the American Chamber of Commerce said in February, which analysts have said could involve moving assets and foreign staff.

;

;Singapore makes sense for Taiwan because of its geographic proximity, its role in the growing supply chains of Southeast Asia, and its reputation for rule of law, according to Wen Wei Tan, an analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit.

;

;Taiwan stands to lose investment, supply chains, if PLA keeps up drills

;

;Some offshore investors reach Singapore on their way to buying fixed assets, such as factories, in neighbouring Malaysia or Indonesia, said Song Seng Wun, a Singapore-based economist at CIMB Private Banking.

;

;They view their money as being “safe” in Singapore, he added.

;

;A spokeswoman for Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry said the city state draws foreign capital because of its “clear policies and reputation as a stable and neutral country”.

;

;Louis Liu, founder and CEO of Taiwan-based family investment office Mimesis Capital, said he is considering opening an account in Singapore because of “demand” in Southeast Asia, while he also sees possibilities in cross-border trade around Asia.

;

;Mainland Chinese also increased their exposure to Singapore over the past two years, the data official showed.

;

;Inward direct investment from mainland Chinese individuals and institutions reached S$8.7 billion (US$6.5 billion) in 2021 and S$9.28 billion last year, up from just S$2.19 billion in 2020.

;

;Investors in Hong Kong – who analysts believe to be largely mainland Chinese bank account holders – parked slightly more than S$10 billion in Singapore last year, up from S$3.45 billion in 2021 and S$1.68 billion 2020.

;

;“Covid-zero policies and the resulting lockdowns made many successful, rich businesspeople and their families realise the system in China has embedded a lot of institutional uncertainty about their wealth, their business, and their families,” said Chen Zhiwu, chair professor of finance at the University of Hong Kong.

;

;

;Chinese investors wanted to increase their positions in Asia to avoid the impact of virus restrictions, Taiwan-based foreign affairs analyst Wang added, after Beijing only cut back on lockdowns in December and lifted international travel restrictions in January.

;

;But Chinese investors looking at Singapore still worry about “physical harm” in the event of a conflict between the US and China, Chen added.
